paragraphs.text:
%md
# About
**Objective:**
In this lab we are going to transform a heavily normalized database into one big denormalized table that we will store in a Hive ORC format for further processing.
The database is the AdventureWorks database that has been the sample database for Microsoft SQL Server for years.
**File locations:** hdfs:///user/zeppelin/AdventureWorks/
**Successful outcome:** A dashboard providing insights into the provided dataset
**Before you begin:**
**Related lessons:** Reading data formats, Spark SQL

---

%md
# Setup
---

paragraphs.title: Read the data from S3 and store it in HDFS
paragraphs.text:
%sh
rm -f customers.csv
rm -f employees.csv
rm -f orders.csv
rm -f productcategories.csv
rm -f products.csv
rm -f productsubcategories.csv
rm -f vendorproduct.csv
rm -f vendors.csv
wget -nv https://hwu-training-public-repo.s3-us-west-2.amazonaws.com/TOPS/ILT/NG-1.0/DEV/DEV-343/customers.csv
wget -nv https://hwu-training-public-repo.s3-us-west-2.amazonaws.com/TOPS/ILT/NG-1.0/DEV/DEV-343/employees.csv
wget -nv https://hwu-training-public-repo.s3-us-west-2.amazonaws.com/TOPS/ILT/NG-1.0/DEV/DEV-343/orders.csv
wget -nv https://hwu-training-public-repo.s3-us-west-2.amazonaws.com/TOPS/ILT/NG-1.0/DEV/DEV-343/productcategories.csv
wget -nv https://hwu-training-public-repo.s3-us-west-2.amazonaws.com/TOPS/ILT/NG-1.0/DEV/DEV-343/products.csv
wget -nv https://hwu-training-public-repo.s3-us-west-2.amazonaws.com/TOPS/ILT/NG-1.0/DEV/DEV-343/productsubcategories.csv
wget -nv https://hwu-training-public-repo.s3-us-west-2.amazonaws.com/TOPS/ILT/NG-1.0/DEV/DEV-343/vendorproduct.csv
wget -nv https://hwu-training-public-repo.s3-us-west-2.amazonaws.com/TOPS/ILT/NG-1.0/DEV/DEV-343/vendors.csv
hdfs dfs -rm -f data/AdventureWorks/*
hdfs dfs -mkdir -p data/AdventureWorks
hdfs dfs -put customers.csv data/AdventureWorks/
hdfs dfs -put employees.csv data/AdventureWorks/
hdfs dfs -put orders.csv data/AdventureWorks/
hdfs dfs -put productcategories.csv data/AdventureWorks/
hdfs dfs -put products.csv data/AdventureWorks/
hdfs dfs -put productsubcategories.csv data/AdventureWorks/
hdfs dfs -put vendorproduct.csv data/AdventureWorks/
hdfs dfs -put vendors.csv data/AdventureWorks/

paragraphs.title: Set the data home directory
paragraphs.text: val AdventureWorksHomeDirectory = "/user/zeppelin/data/AdventureWorks/"

%md
# Lab
---

%md
## Explore the data

%md
Use a shell paragraph to list the content of the AdventureWorks home directory

paragraphs.title: 1 - List the content of the AdventureWorks home directory

paragraphs.text:
%md
The orders.csv file is the largest. Let's take a look at its content.

paragraphs.title: 2 - Do a tail on orders.csv

paragraphs.text:
%md
The 'orders' table  contains only numbers and dates, it is the facts table of what is referred to as a star schema database.
The other tables (employees, customers, products) are called dimensions.

%md
## Load the data

Spark has a method that can read a csv file into a dataframe. 
This method has several options such as guessing the schema of the data and leveraging the header of the file to name columns.
Let's see how these work by reading the orders.csv file three times: one without options, one with the header option and one with the header and the inferSchema options.

paragraphs.title: 3 - Test the read options

paragraphs.text:
%md
Let's see if Spark guessed the schema right.

paragraphs.title: 4 - Do a printSchema on the three resulting dataframes

paragraphs.text:
%md
Dates are always tricky. Spark did not get them but did a great job for the rest of the columns.

%md
## Getting the dates right
A little research shows that you have to use two more options to get the dates right: [https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/SPARK-19228] (https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/SPARK-19228)

paragraphs.title: 5 - Add the options described in the link above and print the resulting schema

paragraphs.text:
%md
Getting types correct early on makes your life easier.
These options really saves a lot of coding.
We'll leverage this to load our data in dataframes and we'll also create the corresponding temporary tables.

paragraphs.title: 6 - Load all the csv files in dataframes and create corresponding temporary views

paragraphs.text:
%md
Let's check if our 'orders' table has been loaded correctly.

paragraphs.title: 7 - View the content of the 'orders' table

table.tableOptionSpecHash: [{"name":"useFilter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable filter for columns"},{"name":"showPagination","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable pagination for better navigation"},{"name":"showAggregationFooter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable a footer for displaying aggregated values"}]

paragraphs.text:
%md
## Denormalisation
We are going to add the linked columns to each record of the products table.
We will keep the foreign keys in the record as they might be needed for machine learning algorithms which use numbers rather than strings.
We will store the result in a new permanent table called 'flatOrders' that will hold all the information contained in the star schema.
We will use the efficient ORC format for this new table.
First we need to delete this table if it already exists.

paragraphs.title: 8 - Drop the flatOrders table if it exists

table.tableOptionSpecHash: [{"name":"useFilter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable filter for columns"},{"name":"showPagination","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable pagination for better navigation"},{"name":"showAggregationFooter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable a footer for displaying aggregated values"}]

paragraphs.title: 9 - Flatten the orders table into a flatOrders permanent table stored as ORC

table.tableOptionSpecHash: [{"name":"useFilter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable filter for columns"},{"name":"showPagination","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable pagination for better navigation"},{"name":"showAggregationFooter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable a footer for displaying aggregated values"}]

paragraphs.text:
%md
Let's check that the table has been created accordingly.

paragraphs.title: 10 - Use the Show create table command to confirm that the table is stored using the ORC format
paragraphs.text:
%sql
SHOW CREATE TABLE flatorders

table.tableOptionSpecHash: [{"name":"useFilter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable filter for columns"},{"name":"showPagination","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable pagination for better navigation"},{"name":"showAggregationFooter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable a footer for displaying aggregated values"}]

paragraphs.text:
%md
## Leverage the new table to explore the data

paragraphs.title: 11 - What are the 10 most successful products?
12 - Who are the 10 most successful sales representatives?
13 - What are the 10 most successful countries?
14 - Use the pivot table function

paragraphs.text:
%md
# Result
**You have now:** created an insightful dashboard with the data from this company using Spark DataFrames

---

%md
# Solution
---

paragraphs.title: 1 - List the content of the AdventureWorks home directory
paragraphs.text:
%sh
hdfs dfs -ls data/AdventureWorks

paragraphs.title: 2 - Do a tail on orders.csv
paragraphs.text:
%sh
hdfs dfs -tail  data/AdventureWorks/orders.csv

paragraphs.title: 3 - Test the read options
paragraphs.text:
val test1 = spark.read.csv(AdventureWorksHomeDirectory + "orders.csv")
val test2 = spark.read.option("header", "true").csv(AdventureWorksHomeDirectory + "orders.csv")
val test3 = spark.read.option("header", "true").option("inferSchema","true").csv(AdventureWorksHomeDirectory + "orders.csv")

paragraphs.title: 4 - Do a printSchema on the three resulting dataframes
paragraphs.text:
test1.printSchema()
test2.printSchema()
test3.printSchema()

paragraphs.title: 5 - Add the options described in the link above and print the resulting schema
paragraphs.text:
val test4 = spark.read.option("header", "true")
                      .option("inferSchema","true")
                      .option("dateFormat","mm/dd/yyyy")
                      .option("timestampFormat", "mm/dd/yyyy")
                      .csv(AdventureWorksHomeDirectory + "orders.csv")
test4.printSchema()

paragraphs.title: 6 - Load all the csv files in dataframes and create corresponding temporary views
paragraphs.text:
val customers_DF = spark.read.option("header", "true").option("inferSchema","true").csv(AdventureWorksHomeDirectory + "customers.csv")
customers_DF.createOrReplaceTempView("customers")

val employees_DF = spark.read.option("header", "true").option("inferSchema","true").csv(AdventureWorksHomeDirectory + "employees.csv")
employees_DF.createOrReplaceTempView("employees")

val products_DF = spark.read.option("header", "true").option("inferSchema","true").csv(AdventureWorksHomeDirectory + "products.csv")
products_DF.createOrReplaceTempView("products")

val productCategories_DF = spark.read.option("header", "true").option("inferSchema","true").csv(AdventureWorksHomeDirectory + "productcategories.csv")
productCategories_DF.createOrReplaceTempView("productCategories")

val productSubCategories_DF = spark.read.option("header", "true").option("inferSchema","true").csv(AdventureWorksHomeDirectory + "productsubcategories.csv")
productSubCategories_DF.createOrReplaceTempView("productSubCategories")

val vendor_DF = spark.read.option("header", "true").option("inferSchema","true").csv(AdventureWorksHomeDirectory + "vendors.csv")
vendor_DF.createOrReplaceTempView("vendors")

val productVendor_DF = spark.read.option("header", "true").option("inferSchema","true").csv(AdventureWorksHomeDirectory + "vendorproduct.csv")
productVendor_DF.createOrReplaceTempView("productVendors")

val orders_DF = spark.read.option("header", "true")
                          .option("inferSchema","true")
                          .option("dateFormat","mm/dd/yyyy")
                          .option("timestampFormat", "mm/dd/yyyy")
                          .csv(AdventureWorksHomeDirectory + "orders.csv")
orders_DF.createOrReplaceTempView("orders")

paragraphs.title: 7 - View the content of the 'orders' table
paragraphs.text:
%sql
SELECT * FROM orders

table.tableOptionSpecHash: [{"name":"useFilter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable filter for columns"},{"name":"showPagination","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable pagination for better navigation"},{"name":"showAggregationFooter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable a footer for displaying aggregated values"}]

paragraphs.title: 8 - Drop the flatorders table if it exists
paragraphs.text:
%sql
DROP TABLE IF EXISTS flatorders

table.tableOptionSpecHash: [{"name":"useFilter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable filter for columns"},{"name":"showPagination","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable pagination for better navigation"},{"name":"showAggregationFooter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable a footer for displaying aggregated values"}]

paragraphs.title: 9 - Flatten the orders table into a flatOrders permanent table stored as ORC
paragraphs.text:
%sql
CREATE TABLE flatOrders STORED AS ORC AS
SELECT orders.SalesOrderID,
       orders.SalesOrderDetailID,
       orders.OrderDate,
       orders.DueDate,
       orders.ShipDate,
       orders.EmployeeID,
       orders.CustomerID,
       orders.SubTotal,
       orders.TaxAmt,
       orders.Freight,
       orders.TotalDue,
       orders.ProductID,
       orders.OrderQty,
       orders.UnitPrice,
       orders.UnitPriceDiscount,
       orders.LineTotal,
       employees.ManagerID,
       employees.FirstName AS EmployeeFirstName,
       employees.LastName  AS EmployeeLastName,
       employees.FullName  AS EmployeeFullName,
       employees.JobTitle,
       employees.OrganizationLevel,
       employees.MaritalStatus,
       employees.Gender,
       employees.Territory,
       employees.Country,
       employees.Group,
       customers.FirstName AS CustomerFirstName,
       customers.LastName  AS CustomerLastName,
       customers.FullName  AS CustomerFullName,
       products.ProductNumber, 
       products.ProductName, 
       products.ModelName, 
       products.MakeFlag, 
       products.StandardCost,
       products.ListPrice,
       productSubCategories.CategoryID,
       productCategories.CategoryName,       
       products.SubCategoryID,
       productSubCategories.SubCategoryName
FROM orders
INNER JOIN employees ON orders.EmployeeID=employees.EmployeeID
INNER JOIN customers ON orders.CustomerID=customers.CustomerID
INNER JOIN products ON orders.ProductID=products.ProductID
INNER JOIN productSubCategories ON products.SubCategoryID=productSubCategories.SubCategoryID 
INNER JOIN productCategories ON productSubCategories.CategoryID=productCategories.CategoryID

table.tableOptionSpecHash: [{"name":"useFilter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable filter for columns"},{"name":"showPagination","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable pagination for better navigation"},{"name":"showAggregationFooter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable a footer for displaying aggregated values"}]

paragraphs.title: 10 - Use the Show create table command to confirm that the table is stored using the ORC format
paragraphs.text:
%sql
SHOW CREATE TABLE flatorders

table.tableOptionSpecHash: [{"name":"useFilter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable filter for columns"},{"name":"showPagination","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable pagination for better navigation"},{"name":"showAggregationFooter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable a footer for displaying aggregated values"}]

paragraphs.title: 11 - What are the 10 most successful products?
paragraphs.text:
%sql
SELECT ProductName, sum(LineTotal) AS Total FROM flatorders GROUP BY ProductName ORDER BY Total DESC LIMIT 10

paragraphs.title: 12 - Who are the 10 most successful sales representatives?
paragraphs.text:
%sql
SELECT EmployeeFullName, sum(LineTotal) AS Total FROM flatorders GROUP BY EmployeeFullName ORDER BY Total DESC LIMIT 10

paragraphs.title: 13 - What are the 10 most successful countries?
paragraphs.text:
%sql
SELECT Country, sum(LineTotal) AS Total FROM flatorders GROUP BY Country ORDER BY Total DESC LIMIT 10

paragraphs.title: 14 - Use the pivot table function
paragraphs.text:
%sql
SELECT * FROM flatorders

paragraphs.title: Additional resources
paragraphs.text:
%md

We hope you've enjoyed this lab. Below are additional resources that you should find useful:

1. [Hortonworks Apache Spark Tutorials](http://hortonworks.com/tutorials/#tuts-developers) are your natural next step where you can explore Spark in more depth.
2. [Hortonworks Community Connection (HCC)](https://community.hortonworks.com/spaces/85/data-science.html?type=question) is a great resource for questions and answers on Spark, Data Analytics/Science, and many more Big Data topics.
3. [Hortonworks Apache Spark Docs](https://docs.hortonworks.com/HDPDocuments/HDP3/HDP-3.0.1/spark-overview/content/analyzing_data_with_apache_spark.html) - official Spark documentation.
4. [Hortonworks Apache Zeppelin Docs](https://docs.hortonworks.com/HDPDocuments/HDP3/HDP-3.0.1/zeppelin-overview/content/overview.html) - official Zeppelin documentation.
%angular
